title: Call for brands to intervene in Shenzhen strike talks
text:
Font size Email Print 
A group of unions and human rights organisations have called on clients of the Shenzhen Artigas garment factory - subject to prolonged strike action over a relocation decision - to intervene in negotiations with workers over severance pay. 
In an open letter, signatories of which include Asia Floor Wage Alliance, Solidarity, and Labour Action China (Hong Kong), call on buyers to participate in monitoring Lever Style-owned Artigas and &quotensuring it negotiates with its workers equally" regarding severance payment due upon relocation, social insurance payments in arrears, and other previous labour rights violations. 
Last month, the Hong Kong garment manufacturer said it had so far failed to negotiate an agreement with striking workers at the Artigas factory in Shenzhen, which is a supplier to Fast Retailing, operator of the Uniqlo casual clothing chain. 
The company told just-style it had conducted another round of meetings with workers involved in the industrial action, but that discussions had not reached a conclusion and around 300 workers continued to strike. 
The industrial action began in early June involving around 900 workers following a decision to relocate workers to another facility five kilometres away. The first phase of this relocation was announced in early April. 
In yesterday's (13 July) letter, the groups said management has ignored several request for collective bargaining, dismissed one representative and mobilised policemen to oppress the peaceful strikers. 
&quotWe are now making a solemn appeal to you … to bear the responsibility of ensuring that Artigas complying with Chinese law, with respect to labour and human rights," the letter read. &quotRefusal to negotiate with workers regarding big changes in the key terms of the labour conditions and unpaid the law-mandated social insurance premiums, are indeed breaching China’s Labour Contract Law and Trade Union Law." 
The groups urge all existing clients and potential clients of Artigas urge Lever Style to pay the severance payments and social insurance contributions in arrears to all the affected workers, ensure no retaliation to the strikers, and intervene in the case until it has been fully settled. 
If Artigas continues to ignore workers' demands, the groups say a number of trade unions and global labour groups will protest against the outlets of those brands which have purchased OEM products from Artigas on 15 July.
